etymologies: early 17th century: from medieval Latin praeemptio(n-), from the verb praeemere, from prae ‘in advance’ + emere ‘buy’

definitions: the purchase of goods or shares by one person or party before the opportunity is offered to others

examples.text: the commission had the right of preemption

shortDefinitions: purchase of goods or shares by one person or party before opportunity

definitions: the right to purchase public land by preemption.
shortDefinitions: right to purchase public land in this way

definitions: the action of preempting or forestalling, especially of making a preemptive attack

examples.text: damaging retaliation for any attempt at preemption

definitions: the interruption or replacement of a scheduled radio or television program.
shortDefinitions: interruption or replacement of scheduled radio or television program
